query_name: Account-Level Bug Reporting vs Non-Reporting Comparison
key_findings: Bug-reporting accounts are HIGHLY MORE engaged: 378.50 avg events vs 208.23 for non-reporters (+81.8%)
Bug-reporting accounts have MUCH HIGHER engagement intensity: 89.00 events/user vs 58.17 (+53.0%)
Bug-reporting accounts have LARGER teams: 4.40 avg users vs 3.73 (+18.0%)
Bug-reporting accounts are NEWER: 347.99 days age vs 411.11 days (-15.4%)
Bug-reporting accounts have HIGHER event diversity: 5.00 vs 4.83 event types
Bug-reporting accounts have ALL event types (min 86 events) while non-reporters can have 0
MarTech is OVERREPRESENTED in bug reporters: 25.00% vs 10.00% in non-reporters
HealthTech is OVERREPRESENTED in bug reporters: 20.00% vs 10.00% in non-reporters
FinTech is UNDERREPRESENTED in bug reporters: 0% vs 20.00% in non-reporters
Plan distribution is fairly balanced, with slight Pro overrepresentation in bug reporters

statistical_significance.engagement_lift_per_account: +81.8% more events per account for bug reporters
statistical_significance.engagement_intensity_lift: +53.0% more events per user for bug reporters
statistical_significance.martech_overrepresentation: +150.0% more likely to be MarTech (25% vs 10%)
statistical_significance.healthtech_overrepresentation: +100.0% more likely to be HealthTech (20% vs 10%)

business_implications: Bug reporting is strongly correlated with HIGH ENGAGEMENT - active users find more issues
Larger teams (more users) lead to more bug reports - more eyes on the product
MarTech and HealthTech industries may have more complex use cases that surface bugs
FinTech accounts show NO bug reports despite 20% representation - potentially different usage patterns or higher tolerance
Newer accounts (newer customers) are more likely to report bugs - possibly in onboarding/learning phase
